content:
What is the purpose of the "TERMINATE" message in the negotiation scenario you described?

It seems like it would be more efficient to simply not respond to the negotiation invitation if you're not interested in continuing, rather than sending a explicit message stating that you want to terminate the negotiation.

Am I missing something, or is this a redundancy in the scenario?

Also, what is the purpose of the "I don't want to continue the negotiation, because [reason]" message?

It seems like it would be more efficient to simply not respond to the negotiation invitation if you're not interested in continuing, rather than sending a message stating that you don't want to continue and then providing a reason.

Again, am I missing something, or is this a redundancy in the scenario?

Thanks!

[INSTS]  You're right, the "TERMINATE" message and the "I don't want to continue the negotiation, because [reason]" message are not necessary in the scenario.

The scenario I described was based on a simplified version of a negotiation process, and those messages were included to make it clear when the negotiation was being terminated. However, in a real-world negotiation, it would be more efficient to simply not respond to the negotiation invitation if you're not interested in continuing, rather than sending an explicit message stating that you want to terminate the negotiation.

Similarly, instead of sending a message stating that you don't want to continue the negotiation and providing a reason, it would be more efficient to simply not respond to the negotiation invitation.

So, to summarize, the "TERMINATE" message and the "I don't want to continue the negotiation, because [reason]" message are not necessary in the scenario, and it would be more efficient to simply not respond to the negotiation invitation if you're not interested in continuing.

Thanks for pointing this out, and I apologize for any confusion caused by the redundancy in the scenario.
